name: Clin T
title: Clinical T
notes:
**Note 1:**  If T is Tis, then Behavior code must be 2 or 3 depending on whether it's an in situ or its Paget's disease.

**Note 2:** The importance of specific imaging modalities to estimate tumor size include: mammograms, sonograms, ultrasound, and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) 

**Note 3:** Microinvasion is the extension of cancer cells beyond the basement membrane into the adjacent tissues with no focus more than 0.1 cm in greatest dimension. When there are mutiple foci of microinvasion, the size of only the largest focus is used to classify the microvasion. (Do not use the sum of all individual foci). The presence of multiple foci of microinvasion should be noted, as it is with multiple larger invasive carcinomas. 

**Note 4:**  Dimpling of the skin, nipple retraction, or other skin changes, except those in T4b and T4d, may occur in T1, T3, or T3 without affecting the classification. Assign the appropriate T category based on the tumor size.

**Note 5:** The following descriptions are used with localized tumors. Assign the appropriate T based on the tumor size (T1, T2, T3).

    Confined to breast tissue and fat including nipple and/or areola
    Local infiltration of dermal lymphatics adjacent to primary tumor involving skin by direct extension
    Localized, NOS
    Invasion of subcutaneous tissue
    Skin infiltration of primary breast including skin of nipple and/or areola
    Attachment or fixation to pectoral muscle(s) or underlying tissue
    Deep fixation
    Invasion of (or fixation to) pectoral fascia or muscle
    Paget disease of nipple without underlying tumor and behavior of /3 (invasive) or page disease of nipple without underlying invasive carcinoma pathologically and behavior of /3 (invasive
  
**Note 6:**  Consider adherence, attachment, fixation, induration, and thickening as clinical evidence of extension to skin or subcutaneous tissue and assign T based on the tumor size (T1, T2 or T3).

**Note 7:**  Consider fixation, NOS as involvement of pectoralis muscle and assign T based on the tumor size (T1, T2, or T3).

**Note 8:**  Inflammatory Carcinoma: UICC includes the following definition: "Inflammatory carcinoma of the breast is characterized by diffuse, brawny induration of the skin with an erysipeloid edge, usually with no underlying mass. If the skin biopsy is negative and there is no localized measurable primary cancer, the T category is pTX when pathologically staging a clinical inflammatory carcinoma (T4d). 

**Note 9:**  A clinical description of inflammation, erythema, edema, peau d'orange, or other terms describing skin changes without a stated diagnosis of inflammatory carcinoma should be assigned to T4b. 

**Note 10:**  For assigning the T category, the abstractor should record a stated diagnosis of inflammatory carcinoma, and also record any clinical statement of the character and extent of skin involvement in the text area.  Assign T4b when there is a stated diagnosis of inflammatory carcinoma and a clinical description of the skin involvement is less than one-third (33%) of the skin of the breast or there is a clinical description of inflammatory carcinoma .  Assign T4d when there is a stated diagnosis of inflammatory carcinoma and a clinical description of the skin involvement is greater than one-third (33%) or there is no clinical description of skin involvement.
